content.location: About 60 feet right of Pleistocene Megafauna. Trees block you from making a direct path to the start. Follow the trail to the right and go up the steps.

content.description: Mostly scrambly, with one steep, juggy section 2/3 of the way up.
content.protection:
9 bolts, lower-off biners. You can skip the 2nd and/or 3rd bolts to help with rope drag. It's literally 2nd-class walking between bolts 2-4. 

 If you have a 60m rope, you MUST belay from the ledge with the practice anchors.
content.location: Right of the black stain. The first few bolts take you up a water runoff channel above the belay ledge.

content.description: About three meters of good, dead-vertical climbing in the middle of lower-angle scrambling. There are several different ways to do the crux.
content.location: The steepest part of the main wall. It starts on the ledge with the bush, but if you don't feel comfortable scrambling up to it, then you can start on "Two-Toed Two Step" for the first 3 bolts, and then break right, or start climbing up a few bolts off Pleistocene Megafauna and then go left.

content.description: 5.5 section is the first few moves, then the rest is easier. Ends with big knobby holds.
content.location: Left of the big dead tree.

content.description: Start on Cromulent Choloepus for 3 bolts, then move right to follow the black stained gully. Towards the top, it's practically walking, and I considered ending the route sooner, but I thought walking up the "rocky road" of big quartz crystals and mica deposits was neat.
content.protection: 8 Bolts, lower-off biners. The first bolt may be considered "high", but it's really just a slabby walk up to it. Just don't trip and fall.

content.description: The first part climbs up a bulge, then it turns into slab/thin face.
content.protection: 9 Bolts, anchors with lower-off hooks. Currently shares anchors with Deadly Sin to the right.

climbs.name: Pleistocene Megafauna
climbs.fa: P1 Mike Hilbert, Justin Headley, P2 Justin Headley (Rope solo) '17

content.description:
This route was made so people could learn and practice multipitch techniques in a safe environment. P1 is a slabby 5.7 for a few moves, then the angle eases up. P2, while only 5.3, is actually pretty fun, near-vertical climbing, with big holds. Some people decide to finish on Three Fingers Three Meters to the left of P2. You can link both pitches if you have a 70m rope.

 UPDATE: I installed another anchor half-way up Pitch 1. This is a hanging belay, and was deliberately put in so people could practice belay transitions from a hanging belay, which is more challenging than a transition on a big ledge.
content.protection: First pitch is 5 bolts and chain anchors. 2nd pitch is also 5 bolts and chain anchors. I'd recommend rapping off of the top. Trying to lower or TR is possible but there's a lot of rope drag. If you want to set up a TR for a big party, extend the anchor out a few feet.
content.location: This route starts on the ground (as opposed to some others in this area that start on a belay ledge) below a basketball-sized depression in the rock.

content.description: Short little one-move wonder. Go straight up over the roof.
content.protection: 4 bolts. 1st bolt is shared with Peaceful Pale-throat to the right.
content.location: On the far right side of the crag. Shares a start with Peaceful Pale-throat.

content.description: A combination of technical face climbing, and slightly-overhung juggy climbing. Stay out of the corner to keep the grade accurate. You pull the crux a couple feet above a bolt, so that's a little exciting.
content.protection: 8 Bolts, lower-off biners. One bolt has a chain draw to help with cleaning, since the route trends towards the right. When you're cleaning, lower, unclip the belayer's side of the rope, and clip your side of the rope into it.
content.location: The farthest route to the right. It's in a shady, wooded area. The start is shared with Perezoso Pull-up.

content.description: Starts with blocky scrambling, then a move or two on a vertical section. Finishes with some lower-angle slab/face.
content.protection: 8 Bolts, hook anchors for lowering off. Currently shares anchors with Rainforest Ridge to the left.
content.location: About 30 feet to the left of the big black stain.

content.description: Although the low angle makes the grade 5.4, the holds on this route are small.  The 5.3 or 5.6 to the right feel more secure and are better beginner leads. Start by walking the very low angle slab. The first bolt is a ways up, right when it starts getting steeper.
content.protection: 11 Bolts, lower-off biners. ***If you have a 60m rope, you need to belay on the ledge about 15 feet off the ground. ***
content.location: Immediately left of the black stain.

content.description: Cruxy beginning that requires a bit of thought.
content.location: Follow the trail around the crag to the right, and then uphill. There is a relatively clear path around the vegetation to get to the start.

content.description:
Sloth Slab is an upper-mountain beginner area. Most of the routes are 5.6 or less. I've witnessed many times how the typical 5.6-5.7 Mount Lemmon beginner route can be too difficult or intimidating for a brand-new climber, so I made this area. All the routes are bolted well, so it's a good place for first leads. Still, the cliff's low angle would make any lead fall unpleasant. The rock face itself starts out low-angle and slabby, but some routes actually go through a juggy and near-vertical section. Some anchors can be reached by scrambling to the top of the wall (there is no trail), but honestly it's easier and safer to just lead up a climb. The wall is west-facing, so it goes into the sun at about 11am. Most of the routes that are around the black-stained gully (which is Rocky Road - 5.3) start on the belay ledge about 15 feet up, where two,  two-bolt-anchors exist. On those routes, a 60 meter rope will NOT reach if you belay from the ground. You can anchor into one of the 2-bolt belays if you really want to, but it's mostly there just so people have a safe place to practice anchor building and cleaning.

**** 70M rope recommended **** Tie a knot in the end of your rope ****

 Almost all routes have lower-off hooks or biners at the anchors. You're welcome to lower off them AFTER you've finished climbing, but please toprope off your own gear. The one route that has more traditional chain anchors is "Pleistocene Megafauna", and that was done so people can practice cleaning and rappelling off of the older style of anchors.
